channel.title: cve on shiny-labs
channel.description: Recent content in cve on shiny-labs

item.title: HackTheBox - Netmon [no metasploit]
item.author: shiny-labs@kylma.fr (shiny-labs)
item.description: Reconnaissance export ip=10.10.10.152 Nmap Starting with a Nmap TCP scan to discover used ports and services behind, with our usual options: -sC runs defaults Nmap scripts -sV tries to identify the software versions -oA will output the results in files prefixed by nmap_tcp and using the formats xml, nmap and gnmap -p- will scan all ports and not the 1000 usual ones sudo nmap -O -sV -sC -oA nmap_tcp -p- $ip Nmap scan report for 10.

item.title: HackTheBox - Optimum
item.author: shiny-labs@kylma.fr (shiny-labs)
item.description: Reconnaissance Starting with a Nmap scan to discover used ports and services behind, with our usual options: -sC runs defaults Nmap scripts -sV tries to identify the software versions -oA will output the results in files prefixed by nmap_tcp and using the formats xml, nmap and gnmap -p- will scan all ports and not the 1000 usual ones $ sudo nmap -sC -sV -O -oA nmap_tcp -p- $ip Nmap scan report for 10.

item.title: HackTheBox - lame

item.title: HackTheBox - legacy
item.author: shiny-labs@kylma.fr (shiny-labs)
item.description: Recon Let’s fire Nmap and see if it can find any fun service running on the host! I use an environment variable to store the IP of the machine so I don’t have to type it all the time and I don’t fat finger and scan the wrong machine (that definitely didn’t happen in real life): $ export TARGET=10.10.10.4 $ sudo nmap -T4 -p- -oA nmap_tcp $TARGET Nmap scan report for 10.
